monogr.title: A reuelation of the true Minerua : The effect of this booke. Who on earth be gods: and by what meanes mortall men may bee made immortall
monogr.author: Blenerhasset, Thomas

div.head: The Printer to the Reader.

p.hi: GEntle reader, the intricate sence of some things contayned in this smal treatise, may induce thy doubtfull minde into diuers iudgementes: therefore by obseruing the Alphebeticall order set down in the margent, and so conferring the notes which I haue heare prefixed with the authours discourse, thou shalt (I doubt not,) finde a light sufficient to leade thee thorowe that darknesse, and thou vnderstanding thereby his intent wilt (I hope) remaine sufficiently satisfied, which thing I hartily wishe.

div.p:
BEcause that diuers verie good Philosophers haue interprited this worde * Saturne to signifie the plentifull aboundaunce of a minde endued with true vnderstanding, deriuing it from the greeke woorde 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : because also in his time the golden worlde was in the most flourishing estate: therefore hee is here brought in, as one indued with the true vnderstanding how to gouerne and rule a common weale: and so generally throughout this treatise, when any one whom the heathen for his woorthinesse woorshipped as a god is rehearsed, not the man, but the vertue which made him of so great estimation is to be regarded, and in this place the author with great admiration, finding all vertue, goodnes and godlinesse, to concurre in a woman, because he thinketh it no herisie to affirme that euery good man hauing the place of a Maiestrate is a god: therefore his intent
is, that they whom vertue made goddes, shoulde create this goddesse, the very beloued of God, on whom God hath aboundantly bestowed his great and best blessinges without measure, and thus he taketh his exordium from the Psal. 82 God standeth in the congregation of the gods, &c.

Pallas and Minerua by the authoritie of many Poets woulde seeme both to bee but one: because Pallas the daughter of Iupiter is called by the name of Minerua: yet this is most certayn, we reade but of one Pallas whose name is deriued of 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 : shee is of some called Bellona the goddesse of warre, of other Tritonia, taking that name of the Fenne in which she was first founde: shee was compted the goddesse of humaine knowledge, and Aristotle calleth her Scientiarum & prudentiae dea: but we read of 5. Mineruae: all the Philosophers, and especially Tully (contrary to the opinion of manie Poets) do call one of them Disciplinarum, & Sapientiae dea, the great and greatest goddesse, euen shee who had the knowledge of heauenly wisedome: but howe so euer it was his intent is to showe that worldly wit is of none effect without heauenly wisedome, and for that cause Pallas doth here lament the losse of Mineruae, thinking it not possible that the pollitike lawes of any common weale can bee of sufficient force to beate downe sinne, and to bridle the ranging desires of mans disposition without diuinitie, and that the bodie cānot be brought to obey anie lawe, except that the working of the conscience bee the chiefe cause thereof: and so he proceedeth to his purpose, to prooue that heauenly wisedome is the knowledge and feare of God, and shee which is indued therewith, doth well deserue to be called Minerua, the very true goddesse of wisedome.

Alecto that spitefull furiesse of hell (for so haue the Auncients tearmed hatred and malice) doth vpon no occasion deuise to hurt the happie, and such as by vertue doe ascende vnto the toppe of fortunes wheele, & to aduaunce the vnworthie: therfore here he bringeth in Galathea, a light &
very wanton woman, and thereby may be seene howe blind spite and hatred are: whose desire is alwayes to destroy the vertuous, and to aduaunce the wicked.

There is nothing else contayned in this verse but a Poeticall description of a deuise, such as the Popes holinesse is full of, especially when he woulde extinguishe the light of the Gospel, and as this verse seemeth to haue no sence, so his deuises haue no force, therefore it obserueth a certayne Decorum.
